English[edit]

Alternative forms[edit]

  • vnd (alternative typography) [16th C.]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle English unde (â€œa waveâ€), from either the Old French unde or Latin unda (â€œwaveâ€).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ÊŒnd/
  • Rhymes: -ÊŒnd

Noun[edit]

und (plural unds)

  1. (obsolete, rare) A wave.
  2. (heraldry) A billow- or wave-like marking.

German[edit]

Alternative forms[edit]

  • unt, vnd, vnnd, unnd (all obsolete)

Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German unde, from Old High German unti, from Proto-Germanic *andi, from Proto-Indo-European *hâ‚‚Ã©nti. Compare Dutch en, English and, Danish end.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ÊŠnt/ (standard)
  • IPA(key): /ÊŠn/ (colloquially among many speakers)
  • audio
    		(file)

Conjunction[edit]

und

  1. (co-ordinating) and
    Kaffee und Kuchen
    coffee and cake
    Ich kam, sah und siegte.
    I came, saw, and conquered.
    • 1904, Rudolf Eisler, WÃ¶rterbuch der philosophischen Begriffe, Berlin, volume 1, sub verbo Ich, page 446-457:
      "Das Â»Ich = IchÂ« ist die ursprÃ¼nglichste Erkenntnis, die Urquelle alles Denkens [..], es bedeutet Â»erstens die rein logische IdentitÃ¤t von Subject und Object im Acte des reinen SelbstbewuÃŸtseins, zweitens die reale metaphysische IdentitÃ¤t des setzenden absoluten Ich und des gesetzten begrenzten Ich, und drittens die zeitliche IdentitÃ¤t des Ich in zwei rasch aufeinander folgenden ZeitpunktenÂ« [...]."
  2. (colloquial) links two nouns, often a person and an activity, in rhetoric questions to express an opposition between them
    Er und Abwaschen? Vielleicht einmal im Jahr!
    Him doing the dishes? Maybe once per year!

Usage notes[edit]

As seen in the second example, commas are never used before und in enumerations, even where English punctuation requires this. However, commas are used before und in certain complex sentence constructions.

Interjection[edit]

und

  1. so?, now?
    Und? Wie ist es gelaufen?
    So? How did it go?
